$ egrep "\.java:[0-9]+: warning: " build_warnings.txt | egrep -o "(\[.*])" | sort | uniq -c

This PR involves API changes, I suspect whether it will break current existing topology, especially for the changes in backtype.storm package, whose interfaces are expected to be same as open source storm's.

This PR involves API changes, I suspect whether it will break current existing topology, especially for the changes in backtype.storm package, whose interfaces are expected to be same as open source storm's.

I'm fairly sure that this change is backwards compatible but not positive. I suspect users would get compiler warnings but not a failure. This is what I saw when working on this PR when I added generics to classes link `ReducerMetrics` and `CombinerMetrics` but not the classes that use then.

Still though, I'll run some tests next week before committing these changes to be sure.
Same comment as #515, I think this is safe but I'll run some tests to make sure.
Yes, that seems like a good idea. Will create separate guides for Mac OS and Ubuntu. Also I think we need to refactor the existing compiling guide to suite the new format. Will work on that too..
When the signature can not fit into one line. It is better to put every parameter in a new line.

When a runtime exception is thrown - instead of System.exit(1) - will the executor exit as well?

@kramasamy Good question. We do all the stop() and close() in a finally block, so they will be closed as well. Or a safest way to add a DefaultUncaughtExceptoinHandler and put "System.halt(1)" at the end; but it can potentially hide issues. (It is what heron-instance and metrics mgr are doing now.)
Sounds good!
üëç

@ashvina Agree that those issues can be incrementally resolved. But is it feasible to resolve my comments starting with "TODO(mfu): ..." with adding actual TODO plan/comments? Currently those comments of mine, to some extent, are more like views or opinions, rather than actual TODO plan/comments.

@billonahill - when you get a chance, please take a look at this. As discussed, there is no default during installation. The user has to provide either

--user, installs in the user home directory
--system, installs in the /usr/local/heron directory
--prefix, installs in the directory prefix provided
Let us do this for 0.13.4 since I would like to a code freeze after this - only documentation and bug fixes for 0.14.0
only documentation and bug fixes for 0.14.0  -- also tests, integration tests or unit tests?
üëç
üëç
Separated the mac and linux guides. The current Linux guide is for 14.04, I'll try to get a 12.04 to see weather we need separate instructions. Do we need to test on Cent OS?
Thanks Ashvin. Fixed it.

@billonahill - based on the discussions we had, packages will be installed in ~/heron/package/version, if --user option is provided

```
/Users/kramasamy/heron
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ client
    ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ 0.13.3
    |-- master

```

The guide has sudo apt-get install libtool and apt-get install libunwind8 libunwind-setjmp0-dev at the top. Added the manual installation steps at the bottom as a precaution only if they encounter errors with the apt installed versions. In my Ubuntu installation this was not an issue, but @lewiskan pointed that this can be an issue in AWS (which I couldn't access). I'll test without gperftool manual installation.
Tested without gperftool manual installation and everything works great. Should we remove the last two manual installations of libtool and libunwind?
@supunkamburugamuve - sounds good!. thanks for the write up.

@kramasamy @maosongfu - I have updated the TODO comments with the action items. Please take a look. 
Note: This branch depends on merge request 518 (from @maosongfu) to be accepted into master.
@maosongfu - sounds good!

The tuning section is very small, because it refers to the other sections, like backpressure and spout lag. That is the reason I included it here. An in-depth tuning section can be added later. This is just a primer on tuning. Let me know if you still think that this can be a independent section.

These are all the guidelines that we provide internally (minus summingbird/tsar). Please let me know if I missed anything.

This PR looks good to me. But I reviewed only the functional aspects; please resolve other reviewers' comments before checking in the code.
duplicate of #187
Let us keep in different pages - we have enough material to add already.

Note that heron.proto.api.Topology, included in PhysicalPlan, reflect the actual dynamic running state of the topology.
Query this value in state manager guarantees the correct running state of the topology.

https://github.com/twitter/heron/blob/master/heron/proto/physical_plan.proto#L39
https://github.com/twitter/heron/blob/master/heron/proto/topology.proto#L14
Fixed in #364

@saileshmittal - can you check if this works with old topologies? I mean it does not have to read them - but it should not crash the old UI or tracker - and gracefully skip it.

@prabhuinbarajan and @billonahill - can you review this PR?

BTW, unit tests for schedulers are enabled now under folder: heron/schedulers/tests/java/...
And unit tests for AuroraScheduler and LocalScheduler are there.
You can also add unit tests for reef scheduler on YARN there.
@ashvina - PR #518 is already merged.
@saileshmittal - can you include the feedback from @maosongfu?
@maosongfu - update the PR with your comments. @lewiskan suggested that ~/heron might clash with people who have checked out github heron repo.

I'm not seeing how adding generics could break anything. If generics are added to an interface or class and the consumer doesn't use generics with their objects, that's allowed for backward compatibility. That's why generics could be added to the Collections API in java 6 without breaking consumers. Legacy code would get the "using raw types" warning, but not exception.

See https://docs.oracle.com/javase/tutorial/java/generics/rawTypes.html
See comments in PR #515, this change is safe. `ComponentConfigurationDeclarer` has always taken a generic parameter, it just hadn't used it itself.
+1, assuming these are only used for RPC and not stored on disk ever.
@billonahill - this is stored in zookeeper though!

PR #539 removes rawtypes warnings from Config, Kryo and Serialization classes. Leaves us with this:

```
$ egrep "\.java:[0-9]+: warning: " build_warnings.txt | egrep -o "(\[.*])" | sort | uniq -c
 119 [unchecked]
```

@billonahill , so the idea is that since we are early on in the process, we can make breaking changes now rather than later.

Note that this is a breaking change, and any older topology (with previous execution state) can not be read by new Tracker that is based on this execution state.
Got it. If we're ok with a breaking change at this point then the change seems fine.
